item.title: About
item.description: About Me I did my PhD in the Robert Gordon University, with a SICSA Prize studentship to research argumentation stance mining in social media. I have been lucky to hold many different roles, from software engineering and data science positions in a tech startup in Edinburgh to several research and teaching contracts in the University of Toulouse, the Robert Gordon University, and the University of Nottingham. I have worked in many teams and with a multitude of people of different backgrounds: software engineers, computer scientists, petroleum geologists, education researchers, and many I am forgetting, which has given me a taste for interdisciplinary research.

item.title: Contact
item.description: E-mail Personal: name.surname@gmail.com Professional: name.surname@nottingham.ac.uk If you are a student, I would encourage you to read this small guide to e-mail communication before contacting me. It can change based on circumstances, but my general policy is the following: I do not e-mail or read e-mails during the week-end. I do not e-mail or read e-mails before 9 AM and after 6 PM. I typically check my e-mails at regular, pre-planned intervals.

item.title: Data Science and Machine Learning
item.description: COMP4030: Data Science and Machine Learning Back to modules Teaching team Praminda Caleb-Solly Jeremie Clos Core ideas of the module An opinionated introduction to the core challenges of data science and machine learning. This module will enable you to appreciate the range of data analysis problems that can be modelled computationally and a range of techniques that are suitable to analyse and solve those problems. Topics covered include: basic statistics; types of data; data visualisation techniques; data modelling; data pre-processing methods including data imputation; forecasting methods; clustering and classification methods (decision trees, naÄ«ve bayes classifiers, k-nearest neighbours); data simulation and model interpretation techniques to aid decision support.

item.title: Databases, Interfaces and Software design
item.description: Databases, Interfaces (and Software design) Back to modules Teaching team Stuart Reeves Jeremie Clos Core ideas of the module Understanding the architecture of web applications from data storage to presentation to the users. In this module we focus on the structure of databases, including how to make them fast, efficient and reliable and on the ways of interacting with them via user interfaces. We examine the fundamentals of the relational database model, its mathematical basis, as well as implementations of the model in database management systems (DBMS) and languages to interact with them such as Structured Query Language (SQL).

item.title: Human-AI Interaction
item.description: COMP3074: Human-AI Interaction Back to modules Teaching team Joel Fischer Jeremie Clos Core ideas of the module Understanding the challenges of human-AI interaction from a sociological and technical perspective. This module is part of the Human-Computer Interaction theme, and the Artificial Intelligence and Optimisation theme in the School of Computer Science. It is an introduction to the design of human-AI interaction to ensure the AI-driven systems we built are beneficial and useful to people.

item.title: Sending e-mails and basic academic politeness
item.description: Sending e-mails and basic academic politeness Jeff Leek had an excellent blog post from 2011 on getting e-mails responses from busy people, which seems to have disappeared recently. While his recommendations are quite strict, they are a good idea of general guidelines university students should pick up when trying to communicate with most academics, who are almost always busy people. Here is my expanded version of those rules: RULE 1.
